The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I learned so much about a wide scope of processes and issues surrounding environmental engineering. To name a few:
wastewater treatment
water pollution, and the way in which pollution disperses through water
air pollution
hazardous waste treatement
Incremental lifetime cancer risk associated with certain activities
climate change
and potable water treatment

A basic introduction to numerous aspects of environmental engineering and some of its underlying thought processes. Topics we covered include conversation laws and mass balances (which came up a lot and were very important), population dynamics, risk, water quality and treatment, air quality, the greenhouse effect, and sustainability.
I developed a lot of critical thinking skills about the ways in which water and air move and are affected by us as humans.
This course gives exactly what it says on the tin: an introduction to environmental engineering. I learned about water pollution, air pollution, mass balance, and some organic chemistry.

I learned about various sectors of environmental engineering, including risk, mass/energy transfer, water and air pollution, and climate change and waste treatment. It was a great overview into the field.
Learned a lot of basic quantitative skills in environmental engineering with regards to air and water. Got a solid foundation on what environmental engineering is about.
a basic overview of environmental engineering topics including water treatment, air quality.

Fundamentals of thinking like an environmental engineer, considering various factors when designing a solution to a complex environmental problem; familiarity with basic mathematical models often employed for common environmental systems; introduction to areas and problems most often tackled by environmental engineers.

I learned both how to think more scientifically (I'm an MMES major, and this was my second science credit) and also a lot about environmental engineering. The class covered such interesting topics as wastewater treatment plants, air pollution, and global warming. Very useful things to understand if you want to build an understanding of the systems we build.
I learned about the field of environmental engineering and how to look at and understand (and hopefully solve!) basic problems environmental engineers face.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the strengths of the course would be that it covers a wide range of topics and gives students a wide breadth of knowledge. I think one thing that could be improved is a little bit more review of the basics, especially with environmental chemistry. Additionally, slides more catered to note taking would be nice. Although, there was never a question on a test that I would deem unreasonable, so overall the material presented in class and the material represented on the tests were very reasonable.

Strengths: We covered a lot of ground without getting bogged down with too many details, and I found that very helpful and useful. The math we used was helpful in showing how environmental phenomena could be modeled, and it was coupled with/acted as a supplement to a strong conceptual emphasis. Professor Fortner was wonderful, and it was clear that he was invested in the class. PSETs were not terribly difficult or time consuming, and our class was quick to set up weekly review sessions to check answers with each other--so that was a nice bit of community as well. 

Weaknesses: The conceptual basis of the lectures was great, but they moved through examples and applications of formula very quickly, so PSETs were kind of a self-contained endeavor. All of the formulas and most of the information we needed was easily accessible in the book, but it would have been very difficult to do PSET work based off the lectures. I understand that it's a tricky balance in a intro class where most formulas are just plug & play, but it was something I definitely noticed.
It was an engaging course and I liked listening to lecture and talking with other classmates about the PSETS.

Strengths: The psets and tests were very manageable, though I feel like some of the reading was not necessary. Professor Fortner was aware that this is just an introduction class and didn't demand anything too complicated, which is really appreciated. 

Weaknesses: Some of the problems in the problem set, especially the ones that weren't from the book, required an unnecessary amount of online researching that was quite tedious. Also, Professor Fortner doesn't seem to have a clear idea of what educational background students have coming into his class, so there can be a bit of a disconnect there.

Strengths: course has a great balance of qualitative and quantitative, well-organized and good opportunities to participate in the lecture. Weaknesses: a very broad course so a lot of the quantitative work seems oversimplified to the point that it is not genuinely useful

Strengths: introduces some of the major concepts of environmental engineering
Weaknesses: spends a lot of time on water treatment, though this does seem to be the professors main interest, so it made sense

The course successfully covers the basics of several important domains of environmental engineering and gives the student a flavor of what environmental engineers are concerned with, how they work, what problems they tackle and what tools they use. The course is well structured, tying the units together with common ways of thinking in an order that makes sense. 
However, I think the course would benefit from deeper, more qualitative and freeform explorations of the complexities involved in environmental problems, maybe allowing students to research challenges or solutions interesting to them and discuss with the class pros and cons of several approaches to a big problem. I would say the course relies a bit too much on applying simplified entry-level mathematical models to give a general taste for how real-world issues are tackled, without fully exploring the various factors and competing interests that go into an environmental solution.

Strengths: Professor was great, and the lecture was sort of small which allowed us to engage with the material more rigorously.

Weaknesses: I personally did not engage with our TA that much.

Strengths: Professor Fortner was very knowledgeable and had lots of cool stories to tell alongside lecture content (especially about water treatment). There was a fair workload for the course.
Weaknesses: The class was taught for slides, so we never worked out example problems in class. We also went really fast through the material.

I think it would be helpful to actually work out live example problems instead of just showing worked out solutions on the slides. I also think it would have been helpful to slow down on the complex material (especially the part about the bioreactors).

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Im sure professor knows this, but the only thing that could've been improved would be the mysterious auto-advancing slides on the power points. Other than that, I was extremely appreciative of professor, it meant a lot to me that on several occasions he took the first few minutes of class to check in and ask us how we were doing. I love professor Fortner, and I want to thank him for being a bright light this year.

Professor Fortner was very interactive with us, and that definitely helped with the virtual setting. As for actual class policy, exams were accessible over a period of several days. I didn't personally take advantage of this (I just ended up taking them during the normal class time), but I can imagine that it would be helpful.
I think lecture would have been better in person, but it was still engaging over Zoom.
Take home exams are a blessing. Recorded lectures are great.
This class was fine on zoom -- I would have loved to be in a classroom but that's unhelpable.
They were all good

Generally the course adapted well to a virtual environment; recorded lectures and weekly help sessions helped a lot, although a second help session would have given students more flexibility; exam format worked very well.

Success: Professor Fortner. Engaging fellow, smart, and caring, and it felt easier to learn with him at the helm. 

Honestly, this class did the best it could have in the COVID-19 pandemic, so I don't think there's a ton of criticism I have of it.
I think the lectures were engaging but it would have been helpful to actually work out example problems on ZOOM on a tablet or something instead of just having worked out problems on the slide.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I LOVED THIS COURSE, and what we learned. I think the course was extremely reasonable, however, I do not love writing, so not having the 10 page paper as a requirement was a huge plus for me.

Definitely! This class is a very chill introduction to Environmental Engineering, its concepts, and the ways in which ENVEs think about the natural world. Even if you aren't an ENVE (or if you take this class and through it realize that you aren't), it's still a really interesting and broad grounding in the field.
Yes, I developed a lot of critical thinking from this class. I also feel like I learned a lot about what environmental engineers do, so I would recommend this course to someone who is curious.

Yes, I would recommend this class because I think it's very important to learn about climate change and environmental science in general. But I know there are other classes that do that, so this is a more math-oriented version of that. Take it if you want real-world applications of math for that quantitative reasoning credit.
Yes! I'm not currently looking to major in EnvEng, but I enjoyed learning about environmental engineering. It was a fun introduction to the field and the professor is grea.t

If you don't know exactly what environmental engineering is, do your research before taking this course. By the end of the course, I did develop an appreciation for it and I'm glad I took it, but at some points along the way the material got pretty boring. Professor Fortner is such an incredible guy though and I felt very supported in this class, he really clearly wants all students to succeed.
Yes, the class was very interesting and a good introduction to the field of environmental engineering.

I would recommend this course to students who want to test or pursue further their interest for environmental engineering and see how real-life problems are approached from a quantitative perspective.

YES! Definitely. You have to interested in the subject, because it's not easy and especially not easy if you're not a science person (I am not a science person) but it is really cool if you are into this sort of stuff. And it's practical if you want to discuss water. Professor Fortner is pretty great, but I'm sure whoever is teaching it will also be great because it is a niche enough course to have a fun professor teach it.
Yes! I thought the material covered by this course was really interesting and the workload was very fair.

comments: N/A
weekly help session
none
Lectures were also recorded, but I went to them all live
